Chapter on Mindfulness of the Body, Part 3
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body following the body.
What kind of wind resides in my body, bringing either comfort or discomfort?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see the dry feces wind:

If I eat too much, the wind becomes unbalanced and can cause distress, entering the body's sinews and veins, causing the feces to dry up, and I may defecate only every two, three, four, or five days, with dry and little waste and great pain.
If the wind is balanced, then there will be no such illness.
Having contemplated the dry feces wind, one accurately understands the body.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body following the body.
What kind of wind resides in my body, bringing either comfort or discomfort?
Using their hearing or the divine eye, they see that if these two side winds are not in harmony, what will be the result?
Using their hearing or the divine eye, they see:
If the two side winds move to the sides of the body, the blood will then dry up. Because of the dried blood, one will experience great pain.
If the winds are in harmony, then there will be no such illness.
Having contemplated the two side winds, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, following the body in contemplation.
What kinds of winds abide in my body, bringing either comfort or discomfort?
Using their hearing or the divine eye, they contemplate what kinds of winds abide in their body and what kind of activities they perform.
Using their hearing or the divine eye, they contemplate and see:

There is a wind called blocking the nine orifices that resides in the body. If it is not in harmony, it can cause the nine orifices - the seven orifices of the head and the two orifices for defecation and urination - to be blocked and not pass through. When the nine orifices are blocked, the body suffers, and the in-breath and out-breath are not at ease.
If the wind is in harmony, it makes the body at ease, and one is able to practice the Dharma. Because the wind supports it, the body can move and come and go.
Having contemplated the wind in the nine orifices, one accurately understands the body.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the body internally, following the body in contemplation.
What winds does he see residing in his body, and what work do they do?
He sees with his hearing-wisdom or the heavenly eye that there is a wind called cutting off the body parts. If it is not in harmony, what does it do?
He sees with his hearing-wisdom or the heavenly eye:

If the wind that cuts off body parts is out of balance and not harmonious, the fingers become numb and unable to function, the hands and feet become numb, the thigh sinews become tight and painful, and the nine coarse sinews and blood vessels become taut and tight, causing the body parts to shake and be weak and exhausted.
If the wind that cuts off body parts is in balance, then one will not have the above-mentioned illnesses.
Having contemplated the wind that cuts off body parts, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, following the body in contemplation.
What kinds of winds are there that dwell in my body, bringing either comfort or discomfort?
With his heard knowledge or the divine eye, he sees that there is a wind called 'harming fire' in the body, and what does it do?
With his heard knowledge or the divine eye, he sees:
The power of this wind can remove the heat of fire, causing food to be undigested. Because of undigested food, one no longer thinks of eating. Because of being unable to eat, one loses complexion.
Why does one lose complexion?
because the blood dries up.

When the blood dries up, the flesh then dissolves, because the flesh dissolves, the sinews then shrink, and no longer produce fat, because no fat is produced, the bones also dry up, because the bones dry up, the marrow also dries up, because the marrow dries up, the essence of the whole body is exhausted.
The power of the breath in the heart moves because of the wind.
If the harmful fire wind is in harmony and at ease, then there will be no illness and suffering as described above.
Having contemplated the harmful fire wind, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the body internally, following the body in contemplation.
What kind of wind resides in my body and what kind of activities does it perform?
He uses his heard-based wisdom or the divine eye to see a wind called the wind that cools all parts of the body. What does it do?
He uses his heard-based wisdom or the divine eye to see:

The cold wind makes the body smelly, sweaty, rough, and ugly, with the body wrinkled, emaciated, and hair standing on end, the body giving rise to black sores, pus oozing and rotting, itching and scratching, oozing liquid, or giving rise to red sores or great steam heat;
or the body gives rise to white sores, coarse and large all over the body;
or the body is like the skin of a white elephant, rough and giving rise to sores;
or the teeth become sparse and black, sores grow on the hands and feet like a tired craftsman, the body gives rise to scabs, the hands and feet are always hot, hard, and rough;
or sores grow and rot, the nails become ugly, the nasal septum droops, and the eyelashes fall out;
people despise him, and all benefactors see him with disgust;
flies swarm around him, and the nails fall out;
when sleeping, the breath is confused and turbid, snoring loudly, not wanting to eat or drink or food being undigested, the tongue does not taste flavors.
In this way, the cold wind in all parts of the body causes the body to rot and decay.

If the cold wind in all parts of the body is in balance, then the complexion is lovely, the skin is fine, soft, smooth, and lustrous, and one is respected by the people. Warm sweat and moisture emerge from the pores, and one is free from the above-mentioned illnesses.
Having contemplated the cold wind in all parts of the body, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body according to the body.
What kind of wind resides in my body, either in balance or out of balance, and what kind of activities does it perform?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see:

There is a wind called 'destroyer of strength' that resides in my body. If it is out of balance, it causes fear in the mind, pain in all parts of the body, or the body to be stiff and unpleasant to stretch. Exhalation and inhalation are all uneasy, the body shakes uncontrollably, one cannot wear clothes, and there is a headache.
If one practices meditation, one cannot attain single-mindedness;
Or one may have nightmares, feel dizzy, and vomit;
In beautiful colors, one has inverted views, seeing what is near as far, feeling parched and haggard.
If the breaking wind is in balance and comfortable, then one will not have the above-mentioned illnesses.
Having contemplated the breaking wind, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body following the body.
What kinds of winds are there in my body, and what kind of activities do they perform?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see the body-shaking wind in his body, sometimes in balance and sometimes not, performing what kind of activities?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see:

If the body-shaking wind is not in balance, there is ringing in the ears, the flesh of the arms shakes, and all parts of the body shake as well. One runs around everywhere, not feeling at ease in any one place, and there are no other illnesses.
If the wind that shakes the entire body is in balance, then one will not have the above-mentioned illnesses.
Having observed the wind that causes trembling in all the body, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body according to the body.
What winds are there that dwell in my body?
He uses his hearing or the divine eye to see a hot wind dwelling in his body, sometimes in harmony and sometimes not, what kind of activities does it perform?
He uses his hearing or the divine eye to see:
If this hot wind is not in harmony, whatever one eats that enters the mouth, when swallowed it will be burned. For this reason, the four great elements are not in harmony and cannot grow.
Or the flavors of what one eats do not form two streams, being turbid and impure.
If there is a pure stream, the four great elements grow, but if there is only turbidity, it will be the suffering of illness.
If the hot wind is not in harmony, whatever one eats will be turbid and not pure, and therefore one will become ill.
If the hot wind is in harmony, whether clear or turbid, the two kinds of food flow and the four great elements are equal. Because of equality, it does not become illness.
Having contemplated the hot wind, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body following the body.
What kinds of winds are there in my body, and what kind of activities do they perform?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see:
There is a wind called 'gathering insects'. This gathering insects wind is found throughout the body and can gather and disperse, blocking the upper and lower parts.
From the top of the head to the feet there are ten kinds of insects:
1. Head-moving insects;
2. Bone-moving insects;
3. Hair-eating insects;
4. Ear-moving insects;
5. Nose-dwelling insects;
6. Fat-dwelling insects;
7. Joint-moving insects;
8. Saliva-eating insects;
9. Tooth-root-eating insects;
10. Vomiting insects.
There are also ten worms in the throat and chest:
One is called the eating worm;
Two is called the saliva-eating worm;
Three is called the phlegm-digesting worm;
Four is called the vomiting worm;
Five is called the worm that moves in the ten flavor-flowing vessels;
Six is called the sweet-intoxicated worm;
Seven is called the flavor-loving worm;
Eight is called the air-stirring worm;
Nine is called the flavor-hating worm;
Ten is called the sleep-loving worm.
There are also ten worms that live in the blood and flesh and move:
One is called the hair-eating worm;
Two is called the hole-dwelling worm;
Three is called the chan-duo worm;
Four is called the red worm;
Five is called the juice-eating worm;
Six is called the hair-lamp worm;
Seven is called the angry blood worm;
Eight is called the blood-eating worm;
Nine is called the slimy worm;
Ten is called the sour worm.
These ten worms are born in the blood, and their shapes are either short or round, very small and eyeless.
There are also ten worms that cause pain and appear in the flesh:
One is called the wound-flavor worm;
Two is called the exhausted worm;
Three is called the constricted tendon worm;
Four is called the moving blood vessel worm;
Five is called the skin-eating worm;
Six is called the moving fat worm;
Seven is called the gathering worm;
Eight is called the stinking worm;
Nine is called the sweat-walking worm;
Ten is called the hot worm.
Such worms are born from the flesh.
There are also ten worms that move in the bile:
One is called the black worm;
Two is called the sprout-flower worm;
Three is called the greatly deceitful worm;
Four is called the suvira worm;
Five is called the crow worm;
Six is called the greatly eating worm;
Seven is called the moving heat worm;
Eight is called the greatly hot worm;
Nine is called the flavor-eating worm;
Ten is called the greatly fiery worm.
Such worms move in the yin [parts].
There are ten kinds of worms in the various parts of the body:
The first is called bone-licking worm;
The second is called bone-biting worm;
The third is called joint-breaking worm;
The fourth is called foul-smelling worm;
The fifth is called bone-dissolving worm;
The sixth is called red-mouthed worm;
The seventh is called tou-tou-mo worm;
The eighth is called skin-eating worm;ğŸ”½The ninth is called knife-wind worm;
The tenth is called knife-mouthed worm.
There are also ten kinds of worms that move in the feces:
The first is called birth worm;
The second is called needle-mouthed worm;
The third is called white-jointed worm;
The fourth is called legless worm;
The fifth is called scat-scattering worm;
The sixth is called tri-burned worm;
The seventh is called ruptured-intestine worm;
The eighth is called obstructed worm;
The ninth is called good-looking worm;
The tenth is called anus-wound worm.
Their color is disgusting. These are called the ten kinds of worms in the feces.
There are also ten kinds of worms that move in the fat and marrow. What are the ten?
The first is called hair worm;
The second is called black-mouthed worm;
third, the power-losing worm;
fourth, the greatly painful worm;
fifth, the distressed worm;
sixth, the fire-colored worm;
seventh, the downward-flowing worm;
eighth, the body-root-producing worm;
ninth, the memory worm;
tenth, the joyful worm.
These worms pervade all parts of the body, and can move throughout the body as they wish. They move through all realms and create offenses wherever they go.
This gathering worm wind pervades the entire body, moving through the body as it wishes. In this way, due to the wind, the worms move.
Having contemplated the gathering worm wind, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, following the body in contemplation.
What winds are present in my body and what work do they do?
Using heard wisdom or the divine eye, he sees a wind called 'up and down' in the body, sometimes causing comfort and sometimes discomfort, and what it does:
Using their heard-of wisdom or the divine eye, they see that if the upper and lower winds are not in balance, they act in five places, doing what kind of work?
They create exhalation and inhalation.
People call it life, moving in the heart and head, pervading the body, free and unobstructed. This is the first part of the power of wind.
If the wind is not in balance, it can destroy the body.
This wind also causes excessive saliva in the mouth, makes the body emaciated, and food and drink return to the stomach, coming up and out. This is the second part of the power of wind.
What does it do when it resides in the chest?
If the qi is in the heart, there may be worry or joy.

If the qi moves from the throat up to the head and down into the tongue, according to what is thought, one can speak, can speak words, and contemplate various meanings. This is the third part of the power of wind.
There is also that which always disturbs the body's fire and causes the body to sweat. This is the fourth part of the power of wind.
This wind pervades the body, blinking the eyelids and moving the entire body, and thinking pervades the body.

Relying on the male and female faculties, it can give birth to offspring. If a man and woman engage in sexual activity, the power of this wind can gather semen and blood, causing the woman's hip bones to have more strength. The male and female semen and blood combine to form the body of a kalala.
When the semen is thin, the wind blows it to make it thick, forming a lump of flesh;
after forming the lump of flesh, the five layers of the embryo are born next;
after the five layers of the embryo are born, whether square or round, following the length of the body, consciousness also pervades everywhere, following various appearances.
It is like someone churning milk to get butter. There is milk, water, a jar, and churning. Churning it produces foam. Knowing it is ready, they collect the fresh butter.
In this way, the power of the wind and karmic afflictions can form the body, also like this. This is the fifth part of the power of the wind.

If one eats and drinks, the flavors fill the tongue, throat, and vessels, and the food and drink fill the entire body, down to the pores and nails, increasing vitality and producing color, smell, and taste.
If the wind is not in balance, the downward wind moves upward, producing four kinds of evil, with the qi blocked and difficult to release, causing pain throughout the body.

If it leaves its original location, all the faculties and all the consciousnesses will be disturbed, and one will lose one's life and body. Having abandoned the body, one loses three kinds of dharmas:
First, life;
Second, warmth;
Third, consciousness.
Therefore, the verse says:
When one abandons this body, one loses life, warmth, and consciousness.
One is no longer aware, like a piece of pottery, wood, or stone.
This is called the first evil.

If it is not balanced, it performs a second function. Rough breathing cannot be regulated, and the whole body is oppressed by suffering. When the oppression is extreme, one loses one's life. This is called the second evil.
If this upward wind is not balanced, it performs a third evil. After afflicting the faculties, it creates chaos throughout the body, and one loses one's life. This is called the third evil.

If this upward wind is not balanced, it performs a fourth evil. Either breathing is very heavy or very slight, and one either dies or merely becomes hunched over without losing one's life. This is called the fourth evil.
When sleeping, the breath comes in and out in a timely manner, sustaining life.
Thus, having contemplated the upper and lower winds, one accurately understands the body.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body following the body.
What kinds of winds are there, either comfortable or uncomfortable, and what kinds of activities do they perform?
They see with their wisdom of hearing or the divine eye:

There is a wind called the life wind that resides in the body, which can make the body fat or emaciated, and make the mind attentive. If the wind is not in balance, the mind becomes agitated, one loses all knowledge, and even what one has heard is forgotten. One does not clearly see objects, does not hear sounds, and likewise the nose does not know smells, the tongue does not know tastes, the body does not sense touch, and the mind does not know dharmas, not recognizing self or others.
Having contemplated the life wind, one accurately understands the body.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, following the body in contemplation.
What kinds of winds create what kinds of activities?
He sees with his wisdom of hearing or the divine eye that the agitated mind wind resides in the body, and if it is not in balance, what does it do?
He sees with his wisdom of hearing or the divine eye that this wind:

If there is a problem with my mind, the wind becomes unruly, following the mind's movements, sometimes agitated, sometimes dull, with dry consumption, confusion, or the flavors I eat flowing improperly, thus disturbing my mind, causing me to take no delight in wholesome dharmas, sweating profusely, salivating, and being intolerant of cold sensations;
If I see forms, due to illness, I cannot see forms as they truly are as before, my body is heavy and difficult to control, and my body hair stands on end.
If the wind is in balance, then there will be no such illnesses as mentioned above.
Having contemplated the wind that disturbs the mind, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the body internally, following the body in observation.
What kinds of winds abide in the body, causing comfort or discomfort, and what kind of activities do they perform?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see:
There is a disturbing wind that abides in the body. If it is not in balance, one has many bad dreams, wakes up startled from sleep, and although staying in warmth, always feels cold;
If one sees cities, towns, or people, one sees them as empty, or sees a yellowish color, speaks little, and does not enjoy lying down;
having heard the Dharma before, one forgets it all;
the four elements are disturbed, the flavors one eats stay in the mind, one becomes disgusted without reason, and one falsely sees a mass of ants.
If the wind is in harmony, one will not have the above-mentioned illnesses.
Having contemplated the disordered wind, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body following the body.
What kind of wind performs what kind of activity?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see:
The winking wind resides in the body. If it is not comfortable, one cannot blink.
No other wind is faster than this.
The winking wind goes everywhere and pervades all the sense faculties. If it is not harmonious, it gives rise to this illness.
If the wind is in harmony, one will not have the above-mentioned illnesses.
Having observed the winking wind, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, observing the body.
What kind of wind is there, whether in balance or not, and what kind of activities does it perform?

He sees with his hearing wisdom or with the divine eye that there is a wind called mutual obstruction. When one is about to die, five winds arise, whether in balance or not, and what kind of activities do they perform?
He sees with his hearing wisdom or with the divine eye:

Because the eyes, ears, nose, tongue, body, and mind are destroyed, one is unable to cognize the objects of form, sound, smell, taste, touch, and dharmas. If the wind does not arise, life is not cut off. If it arises, life is lost.
Having observed the five obstructing winds, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, observing the body.
What kind of wind is there, whether in balance or not, and what kind of activities does it perform?
He sees with his hearing wisdom or with the divine eye:

The wind that destroys the embryo resides in the body. If a person's initial consciousness enters the mother's womb, due to the causes and conditions of past karma, it will destroy the embryo at the kalala stage;
If it does not destroy the embryo at the kalala stage, it will terminate its life at the peÅ›Ä« stage. A cold wind enters the womb and causes it to disintegrate;
If it does not terminate life at the peÅ›Ä« stage, it will terminate life when the body is fully formed;
If it does not terminate life when the body is fully formed, it will terminate life when the faculties are fully developed.
According to the lightness or heaviness of one's past killing karma, one's life will be terminated in the womb.
If one did not kill sentient beings in past lives, the winds described above will not be able to harm one.
Having contemplated the wind that destroys the embryo, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, following the body.
What kinds of winds are there, whether in balance or not, and what kind of activities do they perform?ğŸ”½Here, what kind of wind is there in the body?
Using their heard-of wisdom or the divine eye, they see a wind called turning the womb, which resides in the body, sometimes disordered and sometimes not, and what work it does.
Using their heard-of wisdom or the divine eye, they see:
This turning womb wind, due to the sentient being's evil karma from past lives, if it is a male, turns it into a female, or makes it a eunuch, or the fetus dies in the womb, due to evil karma;
If there is no evil karma from past lives, it cannot be harmed.
Having contemplated the turning womb wind, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the body in the body, following along.
What winds reside in the body and what work do they do?
Using their heard-of wisdom or the divine eye, they see the coming and going, running and jumping wind residing in the body, sometimes disordered and sometimes not, what does it do?
Using their heard-of wisdom or the divine eye, they see:

If the past, future, running, and throwing wind is not in harmony, the hands and feet become cramped, the body becomes hunched over, unable to move, eating and drinking relying on others, unable to eat by oneself, the faculties and wisdom are all impure.
If the wind is in harmony, the body can move, come and go, run and jump, and ride up and down.
Having observed the past, future, running, and throwing wind, one accurately understands the body.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, following the body in contemplation.
What kind of wind, whether in harmony or not, creates what kind of karma?

He sees with his hearing-wisdom or with the divine eye that the five sense faculties of the eyes, ears, nose, tongue, and body are created by the karma of the separate winds. The karma-wind blows, and one wind accompanies the eyes.
Among the four great elements, the power of wind is strong, so it is called wind.
This wind can make the four great elements of the eye faculty pure, seeing various forms;
One wind in the ear can cause one to hear sounds, and the nose, tongue, and body are also like this.
One should contemplate these five winds as they are.
If the winds are in balance, there are no obstructions to the five sense objects;
If they are not in balance, there are many obstructions, and one cannot truly know the sense objects.
Having contemplated the five kinds of winds in the eyes, ears, nose, tongue, and body in this way, one truly knows the body.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the body internally, following the body in observation.
What kinds of winds are there, either in balance or not, and what kind of activities do they perform?
He sees with his hearing or divine eye that there is a knife wind residing in the body, either disturbed or undisturbed, and what kind of activities does it perform?
He sees with his hearing or divine eye:
At the time of death, all the knife winds move, cutting up the skin, flesh, sinews, bones, fat, marrow, essence, and blood, causing them to dry up, and the breath is blocked and does not flow;
The body becomes dry and one dies in agony, as if a thousand flaming swords were piercing the body, not even a sixteenth part of it.
If one has good karma, when one is about to die, the knife wind moves slightly, and one is not greatly afflicted.
Having contemplated the knife wind, one understands the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body, following the body.
What kind of wind, whether regulated or unregulated, creates what kind of karma?
He sees with his hearing wisdom or with the divine eye that the needle-piercing wind resides in the body, whether regulated or unregulated, what does it do?
He sees with his hearing wisdom or with the divine eye:

When one's life ends, if the wind is not in harmony, it will spread through all the joints of the body, all the blood vessels, all the sinews, all the branches and bones, all the pores, all the flesh, all the bones, and all the marrow, like burning flames and needles spreading throughout the body, oppressing the human body, like a hundred thousand flaming needles all piercing the body, not even a sixteenth part of it.
If one has good karma from past lives, when one's life ends, this needle-piercing wind will not be very painful.
Having contemplated the needle-piercing wind, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, following the body in contemplation.
What kind of wind, whether in harmony or not, creates what kind of karma?
He uses his heard wisdom or the divine eye to observe a wind called evil yellow that resides in the body. If it is in harmony or not, what does it do?
He uses his heard wisdom or the divine eye to see:

If the evil yellow wind is not in harmony, it causes jaundice, with the mouth dry, the whole body yellow, the face, eyes, nails, and everything yellow, the abdomen swollen and large, with blue-yellow veins appearing on the abdomen, the body weak, food undigested, the mouth bitter, urine yellow, the body emaciated, the eyes seeing all colors as blue-yellow, unable to move, the abdomen always swollen.
If the yellow wind is not in harmony, it causes this illness;
if the yellow wind is in harmony, it does not cause this illness.
Having contemplated the evil yellow wind, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the body internally, following the body in observation.
What kind of wind, whether in harmony or not, creates what kind of karma?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see a wind called 'intestine-destroyer', which, whether in harmony or not, creates what?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see:

If the intestine-breaking wind is not in harmony, if one eats a lot and stretches frequently, it can break the intestines, or if one eats bones mixed with meat, it can enter the intestines and break them, causing food to flow out, the belly to swell and grow, and to experience great pain, unable to eat or drink;

because of the lack of food, the body becomes weak, the hands and feet swell, the lower orifices steam and heat up, all parts of the body are always hot and unstable, the mouth is dry, and one always has nightmares.
The wind in the belly moves, not staying for a moment.
If the intestine-breaking wind is in harmony and comfortable, then there will be none of the above-mentioned illnesses.
Having contemplated the intestine-breaking wind, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the body internally, following the body in observation.
What kind of wind, whether in harmony or not, creates what kind of karma?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see a wind called cold saliva, which, if in harmony or not, what does it do?
They see with their wisdom of hearing or the divine eye:

If the cold saliva wind is not in harmony, the taste in the mouth is sweet, the mind is agitated, not remembering food and drink, if wanting to sit in meditation, then doubt and laziness arise, the tongue is heavy and difficult to speak, or the throat hurts, the breath smells foul, the foul air in the heart rushes up to the throat, the breath is rough and difficult to exhale, not aware of hunger or thirst, the throat is blocked.
If the cold wind is in harmony, then there are no such illnesses as described above.
Having contemplated the cold saliva wind, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the body internally, following the body in contemplation.
What kinds of winds are there that dwell in the body, either in harmony or not, and what kind of activities do they perform?
He sees with his wisdom of hearing or the divine eye that there is a wind called 'injuring the marrow' that dwells in the body. If it is not in harmony, what does it do?
He sees with his wisdom of hearing or the divine eye:

If the marrow-injuring wind is not in harmony, it causes the body to shake, the body is very tired, unable to travel far, often sick, with an ugly complexion, the body is numb, unable to speak much, and the mind is timid.
This person's bone marrow always aches day and night, the body hair stands on end, the veins are weak, and he always suffers from headaches.
Because of this wind, it always moves the brain insects. Because the insects move, it is like being pricked by needles.
If the wind is in harmony, then there are no such illnesses as mentioned above.
Having contemplated the marrow-injuring wind, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, following the body in contemplation.
What kinds of winds are there that abide in the body, either in harmony or not, and what kind of activities do they perform?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to observe and see a wind called skin-harming that abides in the body. If it is not in harmony, what does it do?
Using their heard-of wisdom or the divine eye, they see:

If the skin-destroying wind is not in harmony, it causes the skin of my body to be ugly in color, all rough and coarse, the skin of the body cracked and split, even if ghee and oil are applied to the body, it quickly dries up;

The body, hands and feet are all stiff and straight, difficult to bend and stretch, in dreams one often sees oneself hanging over a steep cliff, warm food and drink tastes cold in the mouth, the tongue is cracked and split, unable to eat or drink.
If the skin-destroying wind is in harmony and comfortable, then there are none of the above-mentioned illnesses.
Having contemplated the skin-destroying wind, one understands the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the body internally, following the body in observation.
What kinds of winds are there that dwell in the body, either in harmony or not, and what kind of activities do they perform?
Using their heard-of wisdom or the divine eye, they see a wind called 'blood-destroyer' that dwells in the body. If it is not in harmony, what does it do?
Using his heard-acquired wisdom or the divine eye, he sees:
The blood-destroying wind resides in the body. If it is not well-regulated, it moves in the lungs and creates two kinds of problems, either upwards or downwards.

If the blood moves upwards, it will cause the blood vessels in the eyes, ears, and nose to become unbalanced, the elements to be uneasy, and because the elements are unbalanced, the body loses strength, the complexion becomes coarse, one is unable to come and go, and the nose always smells bad;
Fellow practitioners will not walk, sit, or stay in the same place as him.
If the blood moves downwards to the large and small intestines, blood will flow and descend, creating three kinds of problems:
First, hemorrhoids;
Second, suffering;
Third, bleeding.
If the blood-destroying wind is harmonious and well-regulated, then one will not have the above-mentioned illnesses.
Having contemplated the blood-destroying wind, one understands the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, following the body in contemplation.
What kinds of winds reside in the body, either in balance or out of balance, and what activities do they perform?
Using heard knowledge or the divine eye, he sees a wind called flesh-destroyer residing in the body. If it is out of balance, what does it do?
Using heard knowledge or the divine eye, he sees:

If the flesh-destroyer wind is out of balance, it causes various boils and diseases in the body, with foul odors spreading throughout. After bursting, it smells even worse, with a lot of thick discharge;
It cannot tolerate cold or heat, cannot tolerate bitterness or hardship, but prefers light, sweet, and cold [foods].
All bodily movements smell rotten and flow out.
If the wind is in balance, then there will be none of the above-mentioned illnesses.
Having contemplated the flesh-destroyer wind, he knows the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, following the body in contemplation.
What kinds of winds reside in the body, either in balance or out of balance, and what activities do they perform?
Using their heard-of wisdom or the divine eye, they see a wind called fat-destroyer. If it is not well-regulated, what work does it do?
Using their heard-of wisdom or the divine eye, they see:

If the fat-destroyer wind is not well-regulated, it causes the fat to increase, the body grows blisters, it is uneven, with hills and valleys, sometimes hard, sometimes smooth, sometimes dull and ignorant, without any sense of touch.
If the fat-destroyer wind is well-regulated, then one does not have the above-mentioned illnesses.
Having contemplated the fat-destroyer wind, one understands the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, following the body in contemplation.
What winds are there in the body, whether well-regulated or not, and what work do they do?
Using their heard-of wisdom or the divine eye, they see the bone-destroyer wind. If it is not well-regulated, what does it do?
Using their heard-of wisdom or the divine eye, they see:

If the bone-destroyer wind is unbalanced, it causes bone pain, the voice breaks and scatters, one cannot sleep day or night, the neck hurts, all the sinews and bones become loose and untreated, the sinews and bones have no strength, the body always aches, one suffers from exhaustion and cannot move, and there is not a single moment of pleasure.
If the wind is balanced, then one will not have the above-mentioned illnesses.
Having contemplated the bone-destroyer wind, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, following the body in contemplation.
What kinds of winds are there that abide in the body, whether balanced or unbalanced, and what kind of activities do they perform?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see a wind called 'destroyer of essence' that abides in the body. If it is unbalanced, what does it do?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see:
If the harming essence wind is not in harmony, it deceives people. If a person sleeps, it teases people and shows people various evil thoughts, causing non-brahma conduct with a deluded mind.
Because the wind is not in harmony, the female ghost that roams at night deceives and destroys reality. In a dream, it violates one, causing one to forget food.
Having contemplated the harming essence wind, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, following the body in contemplation.
What kinds of winds are there that dwell in the body, either in harmony or not, and what kind of activities do they perform?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see a wind called the wrinkling wind that dwells in the body. If it is not in harmony, what does it do?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to observe the wrinkling wind:

If it is not well-regulated, the soles of the feet, the upper part of the feet, the calves, the thighs, the hips, the back, the sides, the breasts, the throat, the neck, the shoulders, the arms, the ears, the eyebrows, and all parts of the body will become wrinkled. The body will have deep wrinkles, either open or closed, and the feet will be cracked.
Even if oil is applied to the body, it will quickly dry up, making one like an old person.
Having observed the wrinkling wind, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body following the body.
What kinds of winds are there that dwell in the body, either well-regulated or not, and what kind of activities do they perform?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to observe and see a wind called 'white hair' that dwells in the body. If it is not well-regulated, what does it do?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to observe:

If the white hair wind is not in harmony, it can cause young people to have white hair and be emaciated like old people. If a householder's son is like his father, he will age quickly. Because of his son's illness, he will have no more sons.
By the power of the wind, it causes the young to be no different from the old.
This white hair wind arises in a bad kalpa, following sentient beings who do not practice in accordance with the Dharma, and the wind then increases.
If there is merit, the wind will be in harmony;
if there is no merit, the wind will be unruly.
Having contemplated the white hair wind, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, following the body in contemplation.
What kind of wind, whether in harmony or not, creates what kind of karma?
He sees with his hearing wisdom or with the divine eye that there is a wind called 'damaging and greasy' that resides in the body. If it is not in harmony, what does it do?
He contemplates with his hearing wisdom or with the divine eye:
If the damaging-grease wind is unbalanced, one does not remember food and drink, causing one to become weak and not enjoy greasy food;
The origin of the illness is due to daytime sleep.
If the wind is unbalanced, one does not enjoy sweet food but craves bitter and sour flavors;
If one does not eat grease, the wind will be balanced and the body will not be exhausted.
Having observed the damaging-grease wind, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, observing the body.
What kinds of winds are there that dwell in the body, either balanced or unbalanced, and what kind of activities do they perform?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see the drizzling wind that dwells in the human body. If it is unbalanced, what does it do?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see:

If the drizzling disease wind is unbalanced, one always drizzles excessively and cannot do as one wishes. The body lacks strength, the breath is coarse and unbalanced, the complexion is yellowish and emaciated, and one is haggard.
If the wind is in harmony, then there will be none of the above-mentioned illnesses.
Having contemplated the drizzling wind, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, following the body in contemplation.
What kind of wind performs what kind of activity?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see a wind called food-related. If it is in harmony or not, what does it do?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see:
If the food-related wind is not in harmony, the four or five parts of food eaten are vomited out in three parts, causing the mind to be confused, losing the power of food, unable to blink.
Because of the power of the wind, the mind and dharmas are unstable.
If the wind is in harmony, then there will be none of the above-mentioned illnesses.
Having contemplated the food-related wind, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, following the body in contemplation.
What kinds of winds reside in the body, sometimes in harmony and sometimes not, and what work do they do?
He uses heard knowledge or the divine eye to see a wind called destroyer of teeth residing in the body, what does it do?
He uses heard knowledge or the divine eye to see:

If the wind that destroys teeth is not in harmony, the teeth ache, are destroyed and fall out, the gums rot with blood, sores appear on the lips, sores appear on the palate, and the nose is blocked and cannot breathe.
If the wind is in harmony, then there are none of the above-mentioned illnesses.
Having contemplated the wind that destroys teeth, one understands the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, following the body in contemplation.
What kinds of winds reside in the body, sometimes in harmony and sometimes not, and what work do they do?
He uses heard knowledge or the divine eye to see a wind called throat-vessel residing in the body, if it is not in harmony, what does it do?
Using their heard-based wisdom or the divine eye, they see:
If the wind in the throat is not in harmony, it can cause pain in the throat or swelling of the throat, or make the voice hoarse.
If the wind is in harmony, then there will be none of the above-mentioned illnesses.
Having contemplated the wind in the throat, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, observing the body.
What kinds of winds are there in the body, whether in harmony or not, and what kind of work do they do?
Using their heard-based wisdom or the divine eye, they see a wind called downward movement, which is in the body, whether in harmony or not, and what it does.
Using their heard-based wisdom or the divine eye, they see:
If the downward movement wind is not in harmony, it can cause indigestion, little strength, and undigested food.
Because of the digestion of food, skin, flesh, bones, marrow, and blood increase;
If food is not digested, wind, cold, and bile are all not in harmony.
If this downward wind is not in harmony, it will lose the power of food, and due to the lack of food power, the complexion will be haggard.
If the wind is in harmony, then there will be no such illness as mentioned above.
Having contemplated the downward wind, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the body internally, following the body in observation.
What kinds of winds are there that dwell in the body, either in harmony or not, and what kind of activities do they perform?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see a wind called upward movement that dwells in the body, and what does it do?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see:

The upward movement wind dwells at the top of the head. If the wind is in harmony, it emerges from the top of the head like smoke, emerging from above. Whether dwelling in the sun, in the shade, during the day or night, it always emerges without interruption, and ordinary people all see it.
If the wind is not in harmony, then the qi does not emerge;
If the qi at the crown of the head is cut off and does not appear for three days, one will definitely die.
Having observed the upper moving wind, one should know the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally, following the body.
What kinds of winds are there in the body, whether in balance or not, and what kind of activities do they perform?
He sees with his hearing wisdom or with the divine eye that there is a sideways wind in the body, which, if in balance or not, does what?
He sees with his hearing wisdom or with the divine eye that the sideways wind:

If it is not in harmony, it blocks the inhalation and exhalation, causing all the sinews and blood vessels to contract, either gathering or dispersing, either pulling or dragging, or the nose twitching and making a sucking sound, followed by great suffering.
If the sideways wind is in balance, then there will be none of the above-mentioned illnesses.
Having contemplated the sideways wind, one should know the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally, following the body.
What kinds of winds reside in the body, causing it to be either well-regulated or not, and what kind of work do they do?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see a wind called twisting sinews that resides in the body. If it is not well-regulated, what does it do?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see:

If the twisting sinews wind is not well-regulated, it causes the sinews of the hands, feet, and anus, the sinews of the back, and the sinews throughout the body to all twist together, merging into one place, becoming hard and numb, with no sensation.
If the wind is well-regulated, then there will be none of the above-mentioned illnesses.
Having contemplated the twisting sinews wind, one accurately understands the body.
Furthermore, the practitioner internally observes the body following the body.
What kinds of winds reside in the body, causing it to be either well-regulated or not, and what kind of work do they do?
Using their heard-of wisdom or the divine eye, they see a wind called hair-destroyer residing in the body. If it is disturbed, what does it do?
Using their heard-of wisdom or the divine eye, they see:
If the hair-destroyer wind is disturbed, all the body hairs fall out, the body becomes emaciated, and even if the hairs grow back, they fall out again.
If the wind is in harmony, then there will be no such illness as described above.
Having contemplated the hair-destroyer wind, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, following the body in contemplation.
What winds reside in the body, and if disturbed or in harmony, what work do they do?
Using their heard-of wisdom or the divine eye, they see a wind called 'like little wind'. If the wind is in harmony, what does it do?
Using their heard-of wisdom or the divine eye, they see:
Because it is well-regulated, the ten periods of wind power are similar in appearance, color, strength, bending, bowing, and raising.
If the wind is not well-regulated, the mind and intention flow in the veins, which then become agitated, and one develops madness and confusion, with an irregular mind.
If the mind and intention flow in the veins in a well-regulated manner, then one does not become mad or confused.
Having contemplated the wind that is similar to a small wind, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the body internally, following the body in contemplation.
What kinds of winds are there that dwell in the body, whether well-regulated or not, and what kind of activities do they perform?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see a wind called 'fond of sleep.' If it is not well-regulated, what does it do?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see:
If the sleep wind is not well-regulated, when listening to the Dharma, it causes one to become drowsy. Hearing unwholesome dharmas, the mind then delights in listening;
If one wishes to observe correctly during the day or night, one will be disturbed and enjoy going to taverns.
If the wind is in harmony, there will be no such illness.
Having observed the sleep wind, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body, observing the body.
What kinds of winds are there in the body, and what kind of activities do they perform?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see a wind called the anger wind, which resides in the body. If it is not in harmony, what does it do?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see:

If the anger wind is not in harmony, for slight reasons one gives rise to great anger, and one is controlled by anger. All worldly people give rise to great anger, with body hair standing on end, the mind agitated and confused, and one's perceptions unclear, taking what is near to be far;
Seeing the sun and moon, one gives rise to an inverted mind, taking the sun to be the moon and the moon to be the sun.
If the wind is in harmony, there will be no such illness.
Having observed the wind of anger, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body, observing the body.
What kinds of winds are present in the body and what functions do they perform?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see a wind called 'name,' which, if in balance or not, what does it do?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see the wind of names:
If it is in balance, one can speak, and the wind of the tongue speaks according to the mind, following the mental factors, and can speak countless names, phrases, and meanings.
If this wind of the tongue that speaks names is not in balance, one may speak little, make mistakes in speech, or be mute and unable to speak.
